Authors:
Diogo Rezende, Mateus Arduvino Reck, Esteban M. Crespo,
Ricardo Drechsler-Santos, Gerardo Lucio Robledo, Aristoteles
Goes-Neto
Title:
Morphological reassessment and molecular phylogenetic
analyses of Ganodermataceae raised new perspectives in the generic
classification of the family
Abstract:
Ganodermataceae is a remarkable group of polypore fungi,
mainly characterized by particular double-walled basidiospores with a
colored endosporium ornamented with columns and a hyaline smooth
exosporium. In order to establish the basis for a natural classification
of Ganodermataceae, morphological analyses, including scanning electron
microscopy, as well as a molecular phylogenetic approach based on the
Internal Transcribed Spacer and the Large Subunit of the nuclear
ribosomal DNA were carried out with specimens of this family.
Ultrastructural analyses raised up a new character for Ganodermataceae
systematics, i.e.Â is the presence of perforation in the exosporium with
holes that are connected with hollow columns of the endosporium. This
character is considered as a synapomorphy in Foraminisporus, a new genus
proposed here to accommodate Amauroderma sprucei. Furtadoa is proposed
to accommodate species with monomitic context: F. brasiliense, F.
corneri and F. biseptata. Molecular phylogenetic analyses confirm that
both genera grouped as strongly supported distinct lineages out of
Amauroderma s.s. clade. Therefore, a proposal for a phylogenetic
approach of Ganodermataceae is presented.
